docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans will unveil an ambitious agenda topped by changes in Social Security and the tax code on Monday. The chief House tax writer, meanwhile, is urging a broadening of the debate in Congress on paying for retirement programs. ''I'm willing to look at ways in which we solve our societal problems and not go back to the same old solutions, which have never been long-term solutions,'' Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California and chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, said in a television interview on Sunday. He appeared to rule out an increase in payroll taxes but said he was willing to consider a value-added tax or sales tax.

headline.main: Republican Lawmakers Set for Debut of Agenda Starring Social Security and Tax Code

docs.abstract: Senate Republicans will unveil ambitious agenda topped by changes in Social Security and tax code; Rep Bill Thomas, chairman of Ways and Means Committee, appears to rule out increase in payroll taxes but says he is willing to consider value-added tax or sales tax; both parties in Senate will roll out chief legislative priorities with Democrats hoping to counter Republican majority through defining message of their own; Republicans decline to provide specifics of agenda but say it represents broad approach that will cover domestic and international objectives that mesh with those of White House; comments from several prominent Democrats and Republicans (M)
docs.snippet: Senate Republicans will unveil an ambitious agenda topped by changes in Social Security and the tax code on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN his inaugural address on Thursday, President Bush repeatedly invoked freedom and liberty, telling his fellow citizens that spreading liberty around the world was ''the calling of our time.'' The more direct needs of people back home got five presidential sentences. Mr. Bush never spoke about, say, the freedom of knowing that the rent will be paid, that the refrigerator will be full, that car payments or a round-trip subway ride won't be a burden. Health insurance got merely a glancing reference.

headline.main: Freedom Rings, But the Bills Don't Get Paid

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick column criticizes Pres George W Bush for devoting only five sentences in his inaugural address to direct needs of Americans, like 1,034,415 New Yorkers who visited city-supported food pantries in November 2004, up from 885,400 in November 2003; says most people who use food pantries do so not because they are hungry, but because they are needy and are trying to free up money for other necessities (M)
docs.snippet: The state of our union is reflected in the growing number of people lining up at food pantries.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Road Map to a Digital System of Health Records'' (Business Day, Jan. 19): While digital health records may have many benefits, they may also have negative consequences for those of us who are not covered by employers' insurance and must obtain individual health insurance coverage.

headline.main: Digital Health Records: A Dark Side, Too

docs.abstract: Melissa Sabino letter contends comprehensive digital health records will give insurance companies more ammunition to deny coverage or exclude pre-existing conditions and should not be used without guarantee of universal coverage (Jan 19 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Road Map to a Digital System of Health Records'' (Business Day, Jan. 19):    While digital health records may have many benefits, they may also have negative consequences for those of us who are not covered by employers'...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A huge number of Americans with supposedly good insurance put off necessary health care because of unaffordable out-of-pocket expenses. Any surgeon or surgical specialist can tell you about taking care of patients who hold off proceeding with tests, surgeries or other high-tech procedures because of financial constraints or fear about job security due to an employer's concerns about medical costs and the bottom line. High deductibles deter necessary medical care, interfere with continuity of care and cause patients to question if physicians are first and foremost patient advocates or dedicated to their own bottom lines. Jerry Frankel, M.D. Plano, Tex., Jan. 17 The writer is a board member of the Physicians for a National Health Program, a nonprofit group that supports a national insurance program.
docs.abstract: Physicians for a National Health Program board member Jerry Frankel letter on January 16 article on health savings accounts
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A huge number of Americans with supposedly good insurance put off necessary health care because of unaffordable out-of-pocket expenses. Any surgeon or surgical specialist can tell you about taking care of patients who hold off...

docs.lead_paragraph: Few ousted chief executives appear more committed to reinventing themselves than Stephen F. Wiggins. Recalling the end of his tenure at Oxford Health Plans in 1998, he said: ''There were class-action lawsuits and S.E.C. investigations. I was the Kenneth Lay of the moment.'' Well, it was bad, but hardly an Enron. There were no fraud indictments, although Oxford, the insurer, suffered staggering losses on Mr. Wiggins's watch. At the urging of Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, Oxford agreed to suspend $5.4 million of Mr. Wiggins's $9 million severance package five weeks after his departure.

headline.main: Bouncing Back After a Hard Fall

docs.abstract: Stephen Wiggins, ousted as chief executive at Oxford Health Plans in 1998, remains involved as adviser to UICI, insurer based in North Richland Hills, Tex; says he is planning to visit Europe to look at alternative health care clinics and hopes to be more involved in charity, notably Wiggins Foundation; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Few ousted chief executives appear more committed to reinventing themselves than Stephen F. Wiggins. Recalling the end of his tenure at Oxford Health Plans in 1998, he said:

docs.lead_paragraph: America's governors, struggling for a grip on mounting Medicaid costs, are restricting access, squeezing providers and chipping away at services. But perhaps no one is proposing changes as far-reaching and fundamental as Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida. Mr. Bush is proposing that the state's 2.1 million Medicaid recipients be allotted money to buy their own health care coverage from managed care organizations and other private medical networks. If enacted, the program would make Florida the first state to allow private companies, not the state, to decide the scope and extent of services to the elderly, the disabled and the poor, half of them children.

headline.main: Florida Offers a Bold Stroke to Fight Medicaid Cost

docs.abstract: Florida Gov Jeb Bush proposes state's 2.1 million Medicaid recipients be allotted money to buy their own health care coverage from managed care organizations and other private medical networks; plan would mark first time state put cap on its spending beyond which all services for Medicaid users would cease; federal government and states share cost of Medicaid, which have risen 63 percent in last five years to more than $300 billion per year; even most ardent advocates for the poor acknowledge that Medicaid is unsustainable at current rate of growth; map; graph; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is proposing changes to Medicaid that would allow private companies, not the state, to decide the scope and extent of services.

docs.lead_paragraph: For a brief moment, Dr. Thomas Giannulli, a Seattle internist, thought he was getting in at the start of an exciting new area of medicine. He was opening a company to offer CT scans to the public -- no doctor's referral necessary. The scans, he said, could find diseases like cancer or heart disease early, long before there were symptoms. And, for the scan centers, there was money to be made. The demand for the scans -- of the chest, of the abdomen, of the whole body -- was so great that when Dr. Giannulli opened his center in 2001, he could hardly keep up. ''We were very successful; we had waiting lists,'' he said. He was spending $20,000 a month on advertising and still making money.

headline.main: Rapid Rise and Fall for Body-Scanning Clinics

docs.abstract: Body scanning centers are remarkable story of medical technology bubble that burst; companies marketed CT scans direct to public without doctor's referral and could barely keep up with demand until professional societies warned tests would miss common cancers and require rounds of additional tests to rule out real problems; insurance companies refused to pay, causing scanning centers to cut prices to compete; combination of low prices and reduced business spelled doom; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Hundreds of companies offering CT scans without a doctor's referral have opened, but the medical gold rush is ending abruptly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jill Lee Weinberg, the daughter of Faith Weinberg of Manhattan and the late Paul D. Weinberg, was married last evening to Lyle Jaeger Wilpon, the son of Marjorie and Kenneth Wilpon, also of Manhattan. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler officiated at the University Club in Manhattan. Mrs. Wilpon, 38, is a vice president of Marsh & McLennan, the insurance company in Manhattan, where she recruits sales professionals. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania. Her father retired as the president of an advertising firm bearing his name in Manhattan. Her mother is president of Faith Weinberg Real Estate, also in Manhattan.
docs.snippet: Jill Lee Weinberg, the daughter of Faith Weinberg of Manhattan and the late Paul D. Weinberg, was married last evening to Lyle Jaeger Wilpon, the son of Marjorie and Kenneth Wilpon, also of Manhattan. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler officiated at the...

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the health care industry struggling to keep pace with the expanding requirements for paperwork under managed care, the New York region is confronting an acute shortage of physician assistants and clerical workers at the entry level in medicine, according to government labor statistics and industry executives. Although many see the demand as positive, they also see a downside. The situation may provide ample opportunity for jobs, some experts say, but medical assistant and record-keeping work may lead to few, if any, chances for advancement because of rigorous training and licensing requirements.
docs.abstract: Article on acute shortage in New York region of physician assistants and clerical workers at entry level in medicine; while many see demand as positive, some experts say such work may offer few chances for advancement because of rigorous training and licensing requirements; demand for medical workers appears to be highest in New York, given its concentration of hospitals, clinics and medical offices (M)
docs.snippet: The New York region is confronting an acute shortage of physician assistants and clerical workers at the entry level.

docs.lead_paragraph: TRAVELERS wondering if it's worthwhile to purchase trip insurance may find a lesson in the aftermath of the Dec. 26 tsunami, which struck areas in Asia popular with vacationers. Insurance providers said several provisions of the coverage provided by most comprehensive travel policies would apply to this disaster, starting with medical care and, if necessary, evacuation to a hospital or medical facility. Dan McGinnity, vice president at Travel Guard International, an insurance provider, said that in addition to policyholders who needed medical treatment in Thailand, India and Malaysia, the company had a client who was rescued from the floods in Phuket, Thailand, and needed medical evacuation to her home country.

headline.main: Some Help When Natural Disasters Strike

docs.abstract: Susan Stellin Practical Traveler column, in aftermath of Asian tsunami, on trip insurance; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Travelers have several options for medical insurance when traveling abroad.
